title: Judges Chapter 13 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Judges chapter 13 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Judges Chapter 13 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Judges Chapter 13.

questions.question: Who was the barren woman mentioned in Judges 13?
options: Manoah's wife
Deborah
Hannah
Ruth
questions.correctAnswer: Manoah's wife
questions.explanation: Judges 13:2 states that Manoah's wife was barren and bare not.

questions.question: For how many years did the Philistines rule over Israel according to Judges 13?
options: 40 years
20 years
10 years
50 years
questions.correctAnswer: 40 years
questions.explanation: Judges 13:1 states the LORD delivered Israel into the hand of the Philistines for forty years.

questions.question: What was the angel of the LORD's instruction regarding wine and strong drink?
options: Do not drink wine nor strong drink
Drink wine but no strong drink
Drink strong drink but no wine
No restrictions on wine or strong drink
questions.correctAnswer: Do not drink wine nor strong drink
questions.explanation: Judges 13:4 and 13:7 command the woman not to drink wine nor strong drink.

questions.question: What special vow was the child to keep from the womb according to Judges 13?
options: Nazarite vow
Levitical vow
Prophet's vow
Priestly vow
questions.correctAnswer: Nazarite vow
questions.explanation: Judges 13:5 states the child shall be a Nazarite unto God from the womb.

questions.question: What was forbidden to come upon the child's head?
options: No razor shall come on his head
No crown shall be placed
No cloth shall cover his head
No wreath shall be worn
questions.correctAnswer: No razor shall come on his head
questions.explanation: Judges 13:5 specifically says no razor shall come on the child's head.

questions.question: How did Manoah describe the appearance of the angel of the LORD?
options: Like the countenance of an angel of God, very terrible
Like a man of great strength
Like a shining star
Like a fiery chariot
questions.correctAnswer: Like the countenance of an angel of God, very terrible
questions.explanation: Judges 13:6 says the woman's description of the angel's countenance was very terrible.

questions.question: What did Manoah ask the angel of the LORD in Judges 13?
options: What is thy name?
Where do you come from?
Why have you come?
How long will you stay?
questions.correctAnswer: What is thy name?
questions.explanation: Judges 13:17 records Manoah asking the angel his name.

questions.question: What was the angel’s response when Manoah asked for his name?
options: Why askest thou thus after my name, seeing it is secret?
My name is Gabriel
I am the Lord's messenger
My name is unknown
questions.correctAnswer: Why askest thou thus after my name, seeing it is secret?
questions.explanation: Judges 13:18 shows the angel declining to reveal his name, calling it secret.

questions.question: What did Manoah offer to the LORD on a rock?
options: A kid with a meat offering
A lamb
A burnt offering of grain
A goat
questions.correctAnswer: A kid with a meat offering
questions.explanation: Judges 13:19 states Manoah offered a kid with a meat offering upon a rock.

questions.question: What happened as the flame went up from the altar?
options: The angel of the LORD ascended in the flame
The altar exploded
The Philistines attacked
A dove appeared
questions.correctAnswer: The angel of the LORD ascended in the flame
questions.explanation: Judges 13:20 describes the angel ascending in the flame of the altar.

questions.question: True or False: Manoah and his wife immediately recognized the angel of the LORD at first sight.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Judges 13:16 and 13:21 indicate Manoah did not know he was an angel until after the angel ascended.

questions.question: True or False: Manoah feared that seeing God would cause them to die.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 13:22 records Manoah saying they would surely die because they had seen God.

questions.question: True or False: Manoah's wife believed the LORD would not kill them after accepting their offering.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 13:23 shows Manoah’s wife trusting the LORD would not kill them after receiving their offerings.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The woman bore a son and called his name ______.
options: Samson
Samuel
Saul
Simeon
questions.correctAnswer: Samson
questions.explanation: Judges 13:24 states the woman bore a son and called his name Samson.

questions.question: Where did the Spirit of the LORD begin to move Samson at times?
options: In the camp of Dan between Zorah and Eshtaol
In the temple at Jerusalem
In the city of Bethlehem
In the wilderness of Sinai
questions.correctAnswer: In the camp of Dan between Zorah and Eshtaol
questions.explanation: Judges 13:25 mentions the Spirit moving Samson in the camp of Dan between Zorah and Eshtaol.

medium.title: Judges Chapter 13 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Judges Chapter 13 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with trust in God's promises. Based on Judges 13, what biblical truth would you share?
options: God’s promises are sure and come to pass in His timing
We must rely solely on our own understanding
God does not communicate with humans
Promises are only for the Old Testament times
questions.correctAnswer: God’s promises are sure and come to pass in His timing
questions.explanation: The angel told Manoah's wife she would conceive a son who would deliver Israel (Judges 13:3-5). Manoah's response, “Now let thy words come to pass” (Judges 13:12), shows trust in God's promise. The child was born as promised and blessed by God (Judges 13:24-25).

questions.question: How does Judges 13 teach about the importance of obedience to God’s commands in daily life?
options: Obedience to God’s instructions brings blessing and purpose
Obedience is optional when it feels difficult
God’s commands are only symbolic and not practical
Only leaders need to obey God’s laws
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God’s instructions brings blessing and purpose
questions.explanation: The angel instructed Manoah’s wife to avoid wine, unclean food, and to keep the Nazirite vow (Judges 13:4-5, 13-14). Her obedience was necessary for the child’s divine purpose, showing that obedience leads to God’s blessing and calling (Judges 13:24).

questions.question: A believer is facing temptation to indulge in worldly pleasures. Based on Judges 13, what advice can you give about spiritual discipline?
options: Avoid things that lead away from God’s calling, like wine and unclean food
Indulge in all pleasures because they are harmless
Spiritual discipline is only for pastors
Ignore God’s commands if they seem difficult
questions.correctAnswer: Avoid things that lead away from God’s calling, like wine and unclean food
questions.explanation: The angel instructed strict abstinence from wine, strong drink, and unclean foods to maintain holiness (Judges 13:4, 7, 14). This teaches that spiritual discipline involves avoiding temptations that can hinder God’s work in our lives.

questions.question: What does Judges 13 teach about the role of prayer and seeking God’s guidance in parenting?
options: Prayer and seeking God’s direction are vital for raising children
Parents should rely solely on their own wisdom
Children’s futures are unrelated to parental prayer
Parenting is purely a physical responsibility
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer and seeking God’s direction are vital for raising children
questions.explanation: Manoah prayed for the angel to return and teach them how to raise the child (Judges 13:8). God answered his prayer (Judges 13:9), demonstrating the importance of seeking divine guidance in parenting.

questions.question: How does this passage teach about humility in recognizing God’s power?
options: Recognizing God’s holiness leads to reverence and humility
Seeing God’s power makes us self-sufficient
We can control God’s power through rituals
God’s power is only for the mighty
questions.correctAnswer: Recognizing God’s holiness leads to reverence and humility
questions.explanation: Manoah and his wife fell on their faces in fear after witnessing the angel’s ascent (Judges 13:20). Manoah said, “We shall surely die, because we have seen God” (Judges 13:22), showing deep humility and reverence toward God’s power.

questions.question: A fellow believer is uncertain about God’s plan for their life. What biblical principle from Judges 13 can encourage them?
options: God has a unique calling for each person from the womb
God’s plan is always obvious and immediate
Only leaders receive God’s calling
We have to figure out our purpose alone
questions.correctAnswer: God has a unique calling for each person from the womb
questions.explanation: The angel told Manoah’s wife that her son would be a Nazarite from birth, appointed to deliver Israel (Judges 13:5). This shows God’s sovereign plan even before birth, encouraging trust in His purpose.

questions.question: How does Judges 13 teach about the importance of faith in God’s timing when facing long trials?
options: Endurance and faith are essential during prolonged hardships
God’s help always comes immediately
Trials mean God has abandoned us
We should give up if deliverance is delayed
questions.correctAnswer: Endurance and faith are essential during prolonged hardships
questions.explanation: Israel was under Philistine oppression for 40 years (Judges 13:1), yet God prepared a deliverer through faith and obedience. This teaches perseverance and trust in God’s timing.

questions.question: True or False? Manoah immediately recognized the angel of the LORD who appeared to his wife as a divine messenger.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Manoah did not initially know the man was an angel of the LORD (Judges 13:16, 21). Only after the angel ascended in the flame did Manoah realize his true identity.

questions.question: True or False? The angel of the LORD accepted Manoah’s hospitality and ate the offering they prepared.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The angel refused to eat the bread or meat offering, instructing that the offering be made to the LORD instead (Judges 13:15-16). This shows the angel’s role as God’s messenger, not a human guest.

questions.question: How does Judges 13 instruct about dealing with fear when encountering God’s presence?
options: Fear is natural, but God’s acceptance brings reassurance
Fear means we are condemned
We should avoid any encounter with God
Fear should make us run away
questions.correctAnswer: Fear is natural, but God’s acceptance brings reassurance
questions.explanation: Manoah feared death after seeing God’s angel (Judges 13:22), but his wife reassured him that God accepted their offering and revealed His plan (Judges 13:23), teaching that fear is natural but God’s grace brings peace.

questions.question: What does this passage teach about the importance of spiritual identity and its impact on life purpose?
options: Being set apart as a Nazarite defined Samson’s mission
Spiritual identity does not affect life purpose
Only priests have special spiritual identities
Identity is determined by social status
questions.correctAnswer: Being set apart as a Nazarite defined Samson’s mission
questions.explanation: The angel declared Samson would be a Nazarite from birth, which involved special vows and separation to God (Judges 13:5, 7). This spiritual identity was key to his role as Israel’s deliverer.

questions.question: In the context of family life, what does Judges 13 teach about hope and blessing through children?
options: God can bless barren couples with children who fulfill His purposes
Children are only blessings if they conform to cultural expectations
Barren couples cannot be used by God
Family blessing depends on wealth
questions.correctAnswer: God can bless barren couples with children who fulfill His purposes
questions.explanation: Manoah’s wife was barren, yet God promised and gave a son, Samson, who was blessed and called to deliver Israel (Judges 13:2-5, 24-25). This shows God’s power to bless families beyond circumstances.

questions.question: How does this chapter demonstrate the role of testimony and sharing God’s works in fellowship?
options: The woman shared the angel’s message immediately with her husband
God’s messages are meant to be kept secret
Each person should handle God’s revelation privately
Sharing God’s works leads to confusion
questions.correctAnswer: The woman shared the angel’s message immediately with her husband
questions.explanation: After the angel’s visit, the woman quickly told Manoah what had happened (Judges 13:6, 10), showing the importance of sharing God’s revelations within the family and community for mutual support.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The child born to Manoah’s wife was called ______, and the Spirit of the LORD began to move him at times in the camp of Dan.
options: Samson
Gideon
Samuel
Elijah
questions.correctAnswer: Samson
questions.explanation: The woman bore a son named Samson, and the Spirit of the LORD began moving him as described in Judges 13:24-25, marking the start of his God-ordained mission.

questions.question: What lesson about stewardship and honoring God through offerings is taught in Judges 13?
options: Offerings must be made to the LORD, not to angels or intermediaries
Offerings are unnecessary for God’s acceptance
We should offer gifts to angels for blessings
Only priests can offer sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: Offerings must be made to the LORD, not to angels or intermediaries
questions.explanation: The angel instructed Manoah that if they offered a burnt offering, it must be to the LORD, not to him (Judges 13:16). This underscores proper stewardship and worship directed to God alone.

questions.question: How does Judges 13 encourage perseverance through trials for God’s deliverance?
options: God’s deliverance may come after extended suffering, requiring faith and patience
Deliverance is always immediate when prayed for
Trials mean God is displeased permanently
We should abandon faith if trial lasts long
questions.correctAnswer: God’s deliverance may come after extended suffering, requiring faith and patience
questions.explanation: Israel suffered under Philistine oppression for forty years (Judges 13:1), but God planned to deliver them through Samson (Judges 13:5). This teaches perseverance and trust in God’s timing.

hard.title: Judges Chapter 13 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Judges Chapter 13.

questions.question: What was the primary reason given for the forty years of Philistine domination over Israel in Judges 13?
options: Because the children of Israel did evil in the sight of the LORD
Because Manoah's wife was barren
Because the Nazirite vow was broken
Because the angel of the LORD appeared to the woman
questions.correctAnswer: Because the children of Israel did evil in the sight of the LORD
questions.explanation: Judges 13:1 explicitly states that Israel's evil deeds in the sight of the LORD led to their delivery into the hands of the Philistines for forty years.

questions.question: What is the significance of the angel of the LORD's instructions that no razor shall come on the child's head?
options: It signifies the child will be a Nazarite dedicated to God from birth
It was a cultural custom for all Danites
It was a sign the child would be a priest
It foreshadows the child's future as a king
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies the child will be a Nazarite dedicated to God from birth
questions.explanation: Judges 13:5 clarifies that the prohibition on cutting hair designates the child as a Nazarite, a person set apart to God, which also foreshadows his role in delivering Israel.

questions.question: How does the role of Manoah's wife in receiving the angel's message relate to other biblical women who received divine annunciations?
options: She parallels Hannah and Mary as a barren woman chosen to bear a significant child
She represents a unique case without biblical parallels
She is similar to Deborah as a judge and prophetess
She is the first woman to see an angel in the Old Testament
questions.correctAnswer: She parallels Hannah and Mary as a barren woman chosen to bear a significant child
questions.explanation: Like Hannah (1 Samuel 1) and Mary (Luke 1), Manoah's wife was barren and received an angelic announcement concerning a special child, showing a typological pattern of divine intervention in barrenness.

questions.question: In Judges 13, what cultural or religious practice is indicated by the command to avoid wine, strong drink, and unclean foods?
options: Nazarite vow restrictions
Levitical purity laws
Standard Philistine customs
Sacrificial rituals of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Nazarite vow restrictions
questions.explanation: Verses 4 and 14 describe restrictions consistent with Nazarite vows found in Numbers 6, emphasizing the child's consecration to God from the womb.

questions.question: What literary device is employed in the repetition of the angel's instructions to both Manoah's wife and to Manoah himself?
options: Parallelism
Chiasm
Allegory
Metaphor
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: The angel repeats the instructions to both wife and husband (Judges 13:4-7, 13-14), employing parallelism to emphasize the importance of the Nazarite conditions.

questions.question: What theological theme is underscored by Manoah’s reaction to seeing the angel of the LORD ascend in the flame on the altar?
options: The holiness and fear of God
The power of sacrifice
The rejection of idolatry
The promise of deliverance
questions.correctAnswer: The holiness and fear of God
questions.explanation: Judges 13:20-22 shows Manoah and his wife falling on their faces, fearing death because they have seen God, highlighting the theme of divine holiness and human fear.

questions.question: How does the angel’s refusal to eat the offering connect to broader biblical understandings of divine beings and offerings?
options: It indicates that sacrifices are to be offered to God alone, not to angels
It shows the angel’s disdain for human food
It suggests angels have no physical form
It is meant to test Manoah’s faith
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates that sacrifices are to be offered to God alone, not to angels
questions.explanation: Judges 13:16 clarifies that the offering must be to the LORD, indicating theological emphasis that sacrifices are for God, not for angelic beings.

questions.question: What is the significance of Manoah asking the angel for his name, and the angel’s refusal to disclose it?
options: It reflects the mysterious and ineffable nature of divine messengers
It shows the angel's pride
It indicates the angel is not from God
It is a cultural custom of that time
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the mysterious and ineffable nature of divine messengers
questions.explanation: Judges 13:17-18 shows the angel calling his name secret, highlighting the theme of divine mystery and the limits of human understanding.

questions.question: Which later biblical figure does Samson typologically prefigure, considering his Nazarite status and role as deliverer?
options: John the Baptist
David
Moses
Elijah
questions.correctAnswer: John the Baptist
questions.explanation: Samson’s Nazarite vow and role as a deliverer foreshadow John the Baptist, who also was a Nazarite from birth and prepared the way for salvation (Luke 1), showing intertextual connections.

questions.question: What cultural or historical significance does the location "Zorah" have in the context of this chapter?
options: It is the tribal territory of Dan, highlighting Samson’s tribal identity
It was the Philistine capital
It was a major religious center for Israel
It was the place where the tabernacle was kept
questions.correctAnswer: It is the tribal territory of Dan, highlighting Samson’s tribal identity
questions.explanation: Judges 13:2 and 13:25 identify Zorah as in the land of Dan, underscoring Samson’s tribal heritage which plays a role in his story and Israel’s tribal dynamics.

questions.question: True or False: Manoah's wife immediately recognized the angel of the LORD as a divine being upon his first appearance.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Judges 13:6 indicates Manoah’s wife described the angel’s countenance as 'very terrible' and did not know his name or origin, showing she did not fully comprehend his divine nature at first.

questions.question: What is the significance of the Spirit of the LORD beginning to move Samson in the camp of Dan, as mentioned at the end of the chapter?
options: It indicates divine empowerment for his forthcoming role as judge and deliverer
It signals his rejection by the people of Dan
It implies he was possessed by an evil spirit
It symbolizes his political authority over Dan
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates divine empowerment for his forthcoming role as judge and deliverer
questions.explanation: Judges 13:25 emphasizes the Spirit of the LORD moving Samson, a common biblical motif indicating God's empowerment for leadership and deliverance.

questions.question: How does the narrative structure of Judges 13, focusing on the birth of Samson, function within the broader literary framework of the Book of Judges?
options: It serves as a new beginning or turning point introducing a judge who will deliver Israel
It is an isolated story with no connection to the rest of Judges
It concludes the cycle of Judges with a final victory
It primarily critiques the tribe of Dan
questions.correctAnswer: It serves as a new beginning or turning point introducing a judge who will deliver Israel
questions.explanation: Judges 13 introduces Samson’s birth, marking a new phase in Israel’s deliverance cycle and highlighting the pattern of divine intervention through judges.

questions.question: Which ancient Near Eastern cultural theme is subtly present in the motif of a barren woman conceiving a hero through divine announcement in Judges 13?
options: The hero’s miraculous birth as a sign of divine favor
The importance of warrior cults
The role of temple prostitution
The establishment of dynastic kingship
questions.correctAnswer: The hero’s miraculous birth as a sign of divine favor
questions.explanation: The motif of barren women conceiving through divine intervention is common in ancient Near Eastern literature, emphasizing the hero's special status and divine favor, seen here in Judges 13:3-5.

questions.question: What is implied about the identity of the angel of the LORD based on Manoah's statement that they would surely die because they have seen God?
options: The angel is a theophany, a visible manifestation of God
The angel is a fallen angel
The angel is a human prophet
The angel is a Philistine deity
questions.correctAnswer: The angel is a theophany, a visible manifestation of God
questions.explanation: Judges 13:22 and 21 show Manoah’s reaction that seeing the angel is akin to seeing God, a common biblical understanding of the angel of the LORD as a theophany.

theological.title: Judges Chapter 13 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Judges Chapter 13 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What condition did the angel of the LORD instruct Manoah's wife to observe during her pregnancy?
options: Avoid wine, strong drink, and unclean foods
Fast every other day
Pray continually without ceasing
Offer sacrifices daily at the altar
questions.correctAnswer: Avoid wine, strong drink, and unclean foods
questions.explanation: The angel commanded her to avoid wine, strong drink, and unclean foods to prepare for the birth of a Nazarite child (Judges 13:4, 13:14). This reflects the holiness required by God, consistent with Nazarite vows in Numbers 6:1-4, and the call to holiness in 1 Peter 1:15-16.

questions.question: What special vow was the child to be under from the womb, according to the angel?
options: Nazarite vow
Priestly vow
Levitical vow
Prophetic vow
questions.correctAnswer: Nazarite vow
questions.explanation: The angel specifically said no razor shall touch his head and that he shall be a Nazarite from the womb (Judges 13:5). Nazarite vows are described in Numbers 6:1-21, indicating a set-apart life for God’s purposes, pointing to consecration and separation to God (Acts 18:18 references Paul’s Nazarite vow).

questions.question: What was the primary purpose of the child to be born to Manoah's wife?
options: To begin to deliver Israel out of the hand of the Philistines
To become king of Israel
To be a prophet to the nations
To build the temple
questions.correctAnswer: To begin to deliver Israel out of the hand of the Philistines
questions.explanation: The angel of the LORD stated that the child would begin to deliver Israel from Philistine oppression (Judges 13:5), fulfilling God's covenant promises to rescue His people, similar to deliverances in Exodus 3:7-10 and prophetic hope in Isaiah 61:1.

questions.question: How did Manoah and his wife react after the angel of the LORD ascended in the flame from the altar?
options: They fell on their faces to the ground
They shouted for joy
They immediately offered more sacrifices
They ran away in fear
questions.correctAnswer: They fell on their faces to the ground
questions.explanation: After witnessing the angel's ascent in the flame, they fell face down in reverence and awe (Judges 13:20), demonstrating fear of God’s holiness (Exodus 3:6; Revelation 1:17), recognizing divine majesty and their unworthiness.

questions.question: What was Manoah's initial understanding of the visitor who spoke to his wife?
options: He did not know he was an angel of the LORD
He recognized him as the LORD Himself
He thought he was a prophet
He believed him to be a foreign god's messenger
questions.correctAnswer: He did not know he was an angel of the LORD
questions.explanation: Manoah was unaware that the visitor was an angel of the LORD until after the angel ascended (Judges 13:16, 21). This reflects the mysterious and often veiled nature of divine appearances (Genesis 18:2-3; Judges 6:11).

questions.question: What reason did Manoah's wife give to reassure him that they would not die after seeing God?
options: God would not have accepted their offering and revealed these things if He intended to kill them
Because they were righteous before God
Because they lived in a holy city
Because they had the protection of the priest
questions.correctAnswer: God would not have accepted their offering and revealed these things if He intended to kill them
questions.explanation: She reasoned that God's acceptance of their offerings and revelation of His plan indicated His mercy, not judgment (Judges 13:23), consistent with God’s character as merciful and gracious (Exodus 34:6-7; Psalm 103:8).

questions.question: What was the name given to the son born to Manoah's wife, and what significance does this name hold?
options: Samson, indicating strength
Samuel, meaning 'God has heard'
Saul, meaning 'asked for'
Solomon, meaning 'peaceful'
questions.correctAnswer: Samson, indicating strength
questions.explanation: The child was named Samson, associated with strength (Judges 13:24). This name reflects his God-given role as a deliverer with supernatural strength (cf. 1 Samuel 1:20; 1 Kings 1:11-40 for named sons with divine purposes).

questions.question: What does the Spirit of the LORD doing 'move him at times in the camp of Dan' imply about Samson's calling?
options: He was empowered intermittently by God's Spirit for specific purposes
He was possessed by an evil spirit
He was a regular military commander
He was a priest in the sanctuary
questions.correctAnswer: He was empowered intermittently by God's Spirit for specific purposes
questions.explanation: The Spirit of the LORD moving Samson 'at times' (Judges 13:25) indicates divine empowerment for deliverance, aligning with Old Testament patterns where the Spirit empowered leaders for specific tasks (Judges 6:34; 1 Samuel 10:10; Ezekiel 36:27).

questions.question: What does the barrenness of Manoah's wife symbolize in the biblical narrative?
options: God’s intervention and blessing in the birth of a special deliverer
A curse for the sins of Israel
A sign of her unfaithfulness
A punishment for Manoah
questions.correctAnswer: God’s intervention and blessing in the birth of a special deliverer
questions.explanation: Her barrenness (Judges 13:2) sets the stage for a miraculous birth, a common biblical motif signaling divine purpose (Sarah in Genesis 17:15-19; Hannah in 1 Samuel 1:5-20; Elizabeth in Luke 1:7-13).

questions.question: Why did Manoah pray for the man of God to return and teach them how to raise the child?
options: Because he wanted explicit instructions to fulfill God’s plan
Because he doubted the angel's message
Because he wanted to offer more sacrifices
Because he wanted to name the child differently
questions.correctAnswer: Because he wanted explicit instructions to fulfill God’s plan
questions.explanation: Manoah sought further guidance to ensure they correctly raised the child according to God’s will (Judges 13:8), reflecting a godly desire for obedience (Deuteronomy 6:6-7; Proverbs 3:5-6).

questions.question: What was the angel's response when Manoah wanted to detain him for a meal or offering?
options: He refused to eat and said offerings must be made to the LORD
He accepted the offering and ate
He asked for silver and gold instead
He instructed Manoah to prepare a feast
questions.correctAnswer: He refused to eat and said offerings must be made to the LORD
questions.explanation: The angel said he would not eat Manoah’s bread and that any offering must be to the LORD (Judges 13:16), emphasizing worship belongs to God alone (Exodus 20:3-5; Deuteronomy 12:32; Isaiah 42:8).

questions.question: What theological truth is illustrated by the angel of the LORD being both a messenger and divine figure in this chapter?
options: The angel of the LORD represents a theophany, a manifestation of God Himself
The angel was merely a created being with no divine authority
The angel was a human prophet in disguise
The angel was a symbol for Israel’s conscience
questions.correctAnswer: The angel of the LORD represents a theophany, a manifestation of God Himself
questions.explanation: The angel’s acceptance of worship, divine knowledge, and miraculous acts (Judges 13:19-21) identify him as a theophany, a visible manifestation of God, as seen in Exodus 3:2-6 and Genesis 18:1-3, revealing God's self-revelation to humanity.

questions.question: What does the forty years of Philistine oppression signify in the broader biblical narrative?
options: A period of judgment for Israel’s repeated evil
A time of peace and prosperity
A covenant blessing from God
An unrelated historical event
questions.correctAnswer: A period of judgment for Israel’s repeated evil
questions.explanation: The 40 years of oppression (Judges 13:1) were a consequence of Israel's evil, consistent with biblical cycles of sin and judgment (Judges 2:11-15; 2 Chronicles 36:15-21), reflecting God’s justice and call to repentance (2 Peter 3:9).

questions.question: How does the narrative of Samson’s birth in Judges 13 relate to New Testament themes of salvation?
options: It foreshadows the coming of a deliverer empowered by the Spirit to save God's people
It denies the need for salvation
It predicts the end of the world
It focuses solely on military conquest
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows the coming of a deliverer empowered by the Spirit to save God's people
questions.explanation: Samson’s Spirit-empowered birth and mission (Judges 13:5, 25) prefigure Christ, the ultimate deliverer empowered by the Holy Spirit (Luke 4:18-19; Acts 10:38), emphasizing God’s plan of salvation through the Messiah.

questions.question: What does the angel’s statement about his name being 'secret' teach about God's nature?
options: God’s name and essence are holy and beyond human comprehension
God refuses to reveal Himself to humans
God has no personal identity
God changes His name frequently
questions.correctAnswer: God’s name and essence are holy and beyond human comprehension
questions.explanation: The angel’s refusal to disclose his name (Judges 13:18) reflects divine mystery, consistent with God's self-revelation as holy and transcendent (Exodus 3:14; Isaiah 40:28; Romans 11:33).

questions.question: What doctrinal truth about God is exemplified by His sending an angel to announce Samson’s birth?
options: God’s sovereignty and initiative in salvation history
God’s indifference to human affairs
God’s reliance on human strength alone
God’s absence from Israel’s struggles
questions.correctAnswer: God’s sovereignty and initiative in salvation history
questions.explanation: By sending an angel (Judges 13:3), God demonstrates His sovereign control and active involvement in delivering His people, paralleling angelic announcements in the birth of Isaac (Genesis 18) and John the Baptist (Luke 1), underscoring God’s redemptive plan.
